content.description: Start by climbing The Sherpa Connection and at the seam go straight up. A few thin edges and small knobs provide a passageway up.
content.protection: A few large trees at the top bring lots of webbing or extra rope to bring the anchor point to a suitable location.
content.location: Start next to the pine tree on the obvious ledge and follow the crack trending to the right. At the obvious seam head straight up. There are a few pin scars that offer some nice finger locks. You may prefer to tape your fingers (or you may not)...

content.description: Stay to the right and don't get pulled to your left as you ascend the most prominent portion of the prow. I found the crux to be a tad reachy. May be a little stiffer for shorter people.
content.protection: Anchors at top. I used two #1 camalots and a small pine tree
content.location: A bit of a contrived route IMO. If you stray to far left it gets significantly easier, still it's a good finish to CSTW

content.description: This route starts the same as Phasers on Stun, which a 30 foot walk up a ramp.  Traverse right past the Phasers flake and head up a slightly overhanging blocky section to the summit.  The Kochte Climb Maryland! guidebook has this listed as a 5.2, but with the slightly awkward traverse and the overhanging blocky section, I'm listing it at 5.4.
content.protection: The route is well protected with a standard rack.
content.location: The route begins on the right side of the White Rock wall.

content.description: The White Rocks Classic!!  Start at the large tree on the left end of the ramp and climb the prominent, right angling crack to the top. (30 feet off ramp or 50 feet from ground)
content.protection: Lead this route with a light rack of stoppers and small-medium sized cams.

content.description: The first 30 feet is the same as Sugar & Spice, an easy walk up a ramp.  The last 20 feet is a fun and pumpy flake that angles left and faces right.  The Kochte Climb Maryland! book has it at 5.3, but I think it's arguably harder than Gap of Rohan (which gets a 5.6), so I'm logging it at least at 5.5.
content.protection: The flake takes cams and hexes in the #2-#4 BD cam range.   Build an anchor at the summit to belayer your partner up.
content.location: This route starts on the right side of the main White Rock face.  I'll add some pictures soon in case you don't have the Climb Maryland! guidebook.

content.description: Instead of stretching right, go straight up through the roof to the top. Holds inside the cave can be very slimy - not wet - slimy. A fall while still inside the cave can result in hitting the ground due to rope length and stretch. Helmet highly recommended. Watch the rope carefully - lots of sharp edges.

To the left of the green lichen wall is a semi-cave with a blocky roof. Climb the down-sloping shelves to the left of the roof, stretch or leap to the roof itself, swinging to the far right wall and pull the roof. Finish through another overhanging section to a lichen-coated ramp.  Holds inside the cave can be very slimy - not wet, but slimy.  A fall while still inside the cave can result in hitting the ground due to rope length and stretch.  Helmet highly recommended. Watch the rope carefully - lots of sharp edges.
content.protection: Great tree anchors about 20 feet from the edge.

content.description: Climb up and toward the left
content.location: Start on ramp below Phasers on Shun, left of Dogs of War and right of Force Ten

content.description: Climb the overhanging green lichen-covered wall at the far right of the main climbing area of White Rocks, just right of an imposing roof. Exit wall just right of the roof and finish on Lucifer (the cave roof) to the lichen-coated ramp.
content.protection: Anchors are an easy set at the top for top-roping.  Two large and solid trees are only 15 or so feet from the edge.

content.description: This finger crack starts behind a tree on the left side of the main outcrop and heads straight up passing a small tree to the obvious "gap" in the cliff. Exiting the climb at the top on a couple slab moves may be the crux of the entire route.
content.protection: Standard rack including some bigger gear as you get closer to the "gap."
content.location: Left side of the cliff just to the right of Climber Sensitivity Training Wall. Walk down from the top if leading.

content.description: Climb the face directly above the big black spot.
Climb left side from ramp into left side of overhang. Pass left side of big black spot. Continue up crack at top.
content.location: It's in the center if the face up the ramp below Phasers on Shun (left of center on ramp)

content.description: Pass two finger pockets to a face; climb straight up the face.Â
content.location: Start on same ramp for Hubble and Force Ten. first climb up ramp.. (White Rocks)

content.description: Follow the plentiful thin edges up the steep wall staying to the climbers right of the thick lichen.
content.protection: Possible to build an anchor at the ledge but why not build the anchor at the top of the cliff and continue up Thumbthing Else (5.9)?
content.location: Left most climb on the main wall. Walk off on either side but I found climbers left to be less of a bushwhack.

content.description: This area offers stronger climbers with a bit more challenging climbs than the main crags.  North facing crag and can sometimes receive a strong bite of wind if climbing the near winter season.
